comments.content:
I was hoping someone would spot a match. I didn't.  
I wonder if this is two different scripts. The lower case seems heavier than the upper case. The \_M\_ is a very bad fit for the \_ar\_, it reads like \_Moar\_ more than \_Mar\_.  
As for the \_C\_, it is in the style of Spencerian Script and close versions are found in several fonts. For example the \_C\_ in Ambassador Script CT [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/ambassador-script/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140822080154/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/ambassador-script/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/ambassador-script/")  
or in Parfumerie Script Text [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typesenses/parfumerie-script-pro/text/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140822080154/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typesenses/parfumerie-script-pro/text/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typesenses/parfumerie-script-pro/text/") or in Helinda Rook MT [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/athelinda-rook/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140822080154/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/athelinda-rook/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/athelinda-rook/")  
\_M\_ and lowercase, also Spencerian variations.  
For a good general substitute to your image I like Davison Spencerian HI [http://www.houseind.com/fonts/spencerian](http://web.archive.org/web/20140822080154/http:/www.houseind.com/fonts/spencerian "http://www.houseind.com/fonts/spencerian")  
Don
